data.title: Rasheed Wallace retires from NBA, again: New York Knicks sign Earl Barron before playoff series with Boston Celtics
data.meta_description: Rasheed Wallace announced his second retirement Wednesday, capping (we think) a 16-year NBA career that included 21 games with the Knicks this season.
data.text:
RASHEED_WALLACE_RETIREMENT.JPG

Rasheed Wallace announced his second retirement Wednesday, capping (we think) a 16-year NBA career that included 21 games with the Knicks this season.

(AP photo)

The first-round playoff series between the Boston Celtics and New York Knicks will not feature as many "ball don't lie" shouts as expected.

Rasheed Wallace announced his second retirement Wednesday, capping (we think) a 16-year NBA career that included 21 games with the Knicks this season.

"Rasheed has given this team everything he had," Knicks coach Mike Woodson said in a statement. "He is a winner, true professional and leader on and off the court. Due to his injury, he will not be available to play for us during the playoffs."

Wallace played one season with the Celtics, inspiring a 4,000-word rant from Bill Simmons by chucking up lazy 3-pointers, rebounding relatively little and declining to play much help defense. Legend has it that the center increased his output during the playoffs, but, despite starting Game 7 of the NBA Finals (he scored 11 points with eight rebounds) and producing a couple high-scoring games throughout the 2010 postseason, any improvement was minor. He originally retired after the NBA Finals that year.

Yet let me stop pouring cold water on Wallace, whose career is something we all probably enjoyed at one time or another. Even if we admit that he never quite reached his potential, sports aren't just about who scores the most points or lusts after dominance. Sometimes the most interesting parts of following sports are the realizations that a professional basketball player plays hoops in Air Force Ones, wears sweatpants to practice with the pockets hanging out, immortalized the phrases "ball don't lie" and "both teams played hard," and often loses his temper while speaking to referees.

Head coach Doc Rivers was asked recently whether Wallace playing in the playoffs would get the Celtics a couple points per game in technical fouls.

"I'm hoping," Rivers responded.

Hope no more. If retirement don't lie this time, Rasheed, it's been real.

The Knicks, meanwhile -- perhaps in an attempt to cut off any "they should use their open roster spot on Charlie Ward" jokes -- have signed Earl Barron.
